title: Liberty dodges the costume-drama trap with its debut fashion collection
text:
Dorothea Tanning was a surrealist painter who initially supported herself by rustling up fashion illustrations, fell in love with the artist Max Ernst over a game of chess and eventually married him in 1946 in a double wedding with Man Ray and Juliet Browner.

Now that’s what I call a muse. I discovered Tanning along with Lee Miller and Eileen Agar, another surrealist artist, on the mood-board of Holly Marler, Liberty’s head of design, when I went to preview her debut ready-to-wear collection that arrives on the shop floor in October. There were some Bloomsburyites, such as Vita Sackville-West, on there too.

In case you’re thinking this all sounds a bit fey, Marler, a strikingly graceful 38-year-old...
description: Dorothea Tanning was a surrealist painter who initially supported herself by rustling up fashion illustrations, fell in love with the artist Max Ernst over a game of chess and eventually married him in 1946 in a double wedding with Man Ray and Juliet Browner.
